Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Leica TCS SPE confocal microscope for a shared facility to advance undergraduate research and teaching in the W.M. Keck Science Department
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the W. M. Keck Science Department (Keck Science) of Claremont McKenna College, Pitzer College, and Scripps College to acquire a Leica TCS SPE scanning confocal microscope. Keck Science serves students from three distinct, highly selective liberal arts colleges. A primary departmental goal is to offer a modern education in the sciences through hands-on, investigative, and hypothesis-driven learning. The new confocal capabilities will allow Keck Science faculty to modernize three existing advanced biology courses through specific learning outcomes involving fluorescence analysis of whole tissues, while incorporating current, investigative research projects. This confocal microscope will enhance the research program of numerous Keck Science faculty and their undergraduate students who are investigating a wide range of important topics across the sciences. In addition, it will facilitate exciting science outreach activities with the Scripps College Academy, an academic program developed to serve the needs of female students in Southern California from high schools in underserved areas.

The Leica TCS SPE confocal microscope will substantially enhance the Keck Science research program by elevating current limits of conventional microscopic analysis to achieve high-resolution, fluorescence imaging of thick, intact tissues in 3-D, as well as real-time imaging of cellular processes in live tissues. The new confocal capabilities will dramatically improve ongoing research projects of undergraduate research students and their faculty mentors in Keck Science and nearby institutions in the fields of cell biology, genetics, neurobiology and evolution. These projects include fluorescence analyses of chromatin dynamics; effects of selfish genetic elements in insect tissues; investigations of neuronal structure and function in the avian model system, the zebra finch; and phylogenetically guided analyses of the fine structure and function of the teleost retina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant allowed to co-PIs to acquire a Leica TCS SPE scanning confocal microscope for the W. M. Keck Science Department (Keck Science) of Claremont McKenna College, Pitzer College, and Scripps College. The interdisciplinary Keck Science Department is home to 31 tenure and tenure track biologists, neurobiologists, chemists, physicists, and environmental scientists, but has never had a confocal microscope. This acquisition has elevated our limits of conventional microscopic analysis, as we are now able to achieve high-resolution, fluorescence imaging of thick, intact tissues in 3-D, as well as real-time imaging of cellular processes in live tissues.

In the last three years, this instrument has substantially enhanced the research program of the department and fulfilled important needs for confocal microscopy in multiple advanced courses. This instrument has changed how we do science; it has allowed us to expand and diversify the types of questions we are able to address in our research and teaching laboratories.  It has also allowed us to recruit two top faculty who regularly use the confocal microscope in their teaching and/or research.

The now essential confocal microscope supports the research of numerous Keck Science faculty and their undergraduate students in a wide range of topics across the sciences, and has facilitated exciting science outreach activities to high school students through a partnership with the Scripps College Academy.

Intellectual Merit

The new confocal microscope has dramatically improved ongoing research projects of numerous undergraduate research students and their faculty mentors in Keck Science. These projects include chromosome-level fluorescence analyses of chromatin dynamics; effects of selfish genetic elements in insect tissues; investigations of neuronal structure and function in the avian model system, the zebra finch; phylogenetically guided analyses of the fine structure and function of the teleost retina; studies of Traumatic Brain Injury (mTBI) utilizing the zebrafish brain as a model system; characterizing whether pollination mode and cell shape correlate in Mimulus, a genus of wildflowers adapted to a diversity of pollinators.  Images taken on the confocal microscope have contributed to numerous publications (many of which include undergraduate co-authors).  An image from this microscope was featured on the cover of Journal of Neuroscience.

 Broader Impacts

The W. M. Keck Science Department serves three distinct, highly selective liberal arts colleges, with a departmental enrollment of ~3,000 undergraduates each academic year. A primary departmental goal is to offer modern education in the sciences through hands-on, investigative, and hypothesis-driven learning. The new confocal capabilities have allowed Keck Science faculty to modernize three existing advanced biology courses:  Cell Biology, Developmental Biology, and Neuroscience. These courses now expose approximately 60 students to cutting edge research projects each year. In fulfillment of their senior thesis requirements, many science majors conduct high-quality research projects, many of which are of publication quality. Approximately 8-10 undergraduate research students have made extensive sue of the confocal microscope each year.

This confocal microscope has greatly enhanced our science outreach activities.  We have partnered with Scripps Summer Academy, an innovative outreach program consisting of an intensive summer residential experience and a complementary year-round support program for young women from racially diverse and economically underserved communities in Southern California. For each of the three years of this grant, we ran afternoon workshops students exposing 50 high school students to modern confocal microscopy.
